head.title: U.S. Faces Argentina in Championship Bridge Playoffs

hedline.hl1: U.S. Faces Argentina in Championship Bridge Playoffs

abstract.p: Both US teams finish strongly at end of qualifying stage of World Bridge Championships in Maastricht, Netherlands, and will begin playoff matches against teams from Argentina (M)

block.p: Both United States teams finished strongly at the end of the qualifying stage of the World Bridge Championships here today, and will begin playoff matches Sunday.
In the Open Series, the American team of George Jacobs, Ralph Katz, Howard Weinstein, Steve Garner, David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen outdistanced their rivals in heading qualifying Group B.
Both United States teams finished strongly at the end of the qualifying stage of the World Bridge Championships here today, and will begin playoff matches Sunday.
In the Open Series, the American team of George Jacobs, Ralph Katz, Howard Weinstein, Steve Garner, David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen outdistanced their rivals in heading qualifying Group B.
The standings, with four to qualify, were: first, United States, 346 victory points; second, the Netherlands, 327; third, Russia, 309; fourth, Australia, 305; and fifth, Hungary, 283.

Winning the group gave the Americans limited rights in selecting a playoff opponent; they chose Argentina. Other pairings are the Netherlands versus Iceland; Russia versus Norway; and Australia versus Italy.

here was a fierce battle in Group A for the fourth qualifying spot, and Brazil survived along with Poland, Austria and Belgium. The standings were: first, Poland, 339; second, Austria, 324.5; third, Belgium, 316; fourth, Brazil, 303; fifth, Denmark tied Ireland, 296.5.

In Group C, France, with a team including some world champions, held off Israel to win the crucial fourth position, in spite of a surprising loss to Cyprus, 12-18. The standings were: first, England, 350; second, Indonesia, 334.5; third, Sweden, 320; fourth, France, 311; and fifth, Israel, 303.

In Group D, Iceland finished strongly to ensure qualification. The standings were: first, Italy, 358; second, Argentina, 335; third, Norway, 325; fourth, Iceland, 313; fifth, New Zealand tied South Africa, 310.
Other pairings when the playoffs begin are England versus Belgium; Poland versus France; Indonesia versus Brazil; and Austria versus Sweden.

In the women's teams, the American team of Joan Jackson, Robin Klar, Peggy Sutherlin, Petra Hamman, Shawn Quinn and Mildred Breed recovered from a slow start to the week and also won their group. They were entitled to select their next opponent from the other group and chose Scotland. The standings, with eight to qualify, were: first, United States, 359.6; second, Austria, 356; third, Norway, 352; fourth, England, 347; fifth, Taiwan, 333.25; sixth, Israel, 316.5; seventh, Japan, 308; eighth, Sweden, 306; and ninth, Denmark, 301.5.

In the other group, the standings were: first, Germany, 373; second, France, 368; third, Canada, 356; fourth, the Netherlands, 344; fifth, Poland, 329; sixth, China, 319; seventh, Scotland, 310; eighth, South Africa, 299; and ninth, Greece, 293.

Other playoff pairings in the women's series were Germany versus Japan; Austria versus South Africa; France versus Taiwan; Norway versus Poland; Canada versus Sweden; England versus China; and the Netherlands versus Israel.
